title: How Can You Still Be Catholic?: 50 Answers to a Good Question
features: "How can you still be Catholic?" Cradle Catholic Christopher Sparks takes the question head on, addressing an array of controversial issues and offering the same answer given by St. Peter 2,000 years ago.
description: As a convert to Catholicism, I'm certain this book is going to do a lot of good for many people. Catholics, non-Catholics, atheists, and everyone in between will discover in these pages honest, insightful, respectful, and well-documented answers about the Catholic Church and its teachings. Grounded in faith, reason, and the author's own personal love for Jesus Christ,
How Can You Still Be Catholic?
is a tremendous resource for us all! - Fr. Donald Calloway, MIC, author of
Champions of the Rosary: The History and Heroes of a Spiritual Weapon

When I have a question about Church doctrine, history, or culture, I know I can turn to my friend Chris Sparks for a clear and enlightening answer. With this book, Chris's extraordinary wisdom is no longer just a personal resource for his friends and family but for everyone who sincerely seeks the truth. - Fr. Michael Gaitley, MIC, author of
33 Days to Morning Glory: A Do-It-Yourself Retreat In Preparation for Marian Consecration
Have questions about the Catholic faith? Christopher Sparks has answers. Catholics and non-Catholics alike will find clarity and understanding in
How Can You Still Be Catholic?
An excellent read for doubters, skeptics, and all those just wanting to understand what the Church teaches and why. - Emily Stimpson, author of
These Beautiful Bones: An Everyday Theology of the Body

I love learning about the faith. It was this type of book that helped me enter the Catholic Church in Easter of 1999. I kind of wished this was published back then, but Chris likely wasn't born yet. There are so many misunderstandings and stereotypes about Catholicism. Chris Sparks tackles them one after the other. Whether you are a recent convert, looking into the Catholic faith, a cradle Catholic, or some random person checking religious books out, this has a lot you can get your teeth into. Keep enjoying the journey. - Chris Padgett, author of
I'm Not OK. You're Not OK. But It's OK.

Christopher Sparks has given us a gift: a testimony to the goodness and beauty of Jesus Christ, still present in His Body, the Church, and still giving His gentle and moving grace in this dark age. When so many inside the Church hide His face and so many outside the Church can therefore not see Him, Chris Sparks bears witness as an apostle should. - Mark P. Shea, author of
By What Authority?: An Evangelical Discovers Catholic Tradition

Christopher Sparks has a BA in history and philosophy from Gonzaga University, and an MA in theology from Franciscan University of Steubenville. He has written for Catholic Exchange, Lay Witness magazine, and various publications by the Marian Fathers. He blogs at attheturnofthetide.blogspot.com  Sparks' interest in defending the Catholic faith began as an attempt to find out whether or not it was true. The best way to test it seemed to be to hear the objections of those who attacked it and then to find out if there was any response. After years of pursuing such objections, he came to the conclusion that it was true, largely based on the two points identified by Cardinal Ratzinger as the only two real defenses of the faith: the witness of the lives of the saints and the tremendous contributions of the Catholic Church and her members to human culture.
